content: Thank you all very much for helping me developing my first puzzle!

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Possible to solve in 5 min. Good to CoC.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Fun clash!
Solvable in under five minutes, the statement is short and unambiguous.
All test cases pass without problem.

Nuh, the existence of a global checksum is ok. But the fact that it's not clear how a global checksum may be used is not ok.
I enjoy figuring things out in a stressful environment. But I understand that a lot of people don't anticipate this experience from a Fastest, there is Reverse for that.
You can just add something like
"The third input is a checksum that is constructed by XORing the two ASCII codes and the global checksum."

Interesting puzzle.
However I tend to agree with others, the global checksum is unnecessary and confusing.
It makes you think something more complex is going on when in reality a simple xor of charA and charB is all you need.

I was able to do this exercise but I had to guess how the checksums were used using the hint. I agree with lopidav. The instructions should be explicit with how both the global checksum and per message checksum are used.

I understand that this question is supposed to emulate demodulation, which I appreciate. However, I do not understand the value in having the global checksum. Maybe I lack understanding in demodulation? I would omit the global checksum portion of this question if there is not a reason to keep it. I think it adds unneeded complexity.

Regardless, thank you for making a unique contribution. I can revisit if your prompt is updated.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good one.
Describe better how checksums are constructed tho. That's a part of the puzzle and not just a 'hint'

I like the idea. 
The global checksum has no real use in the challenge. You can leave it out. And  the puzzle is designed it cannot have 2 errors in the same set of 3 binary values. 
I cannot approve unless I check all languages.
I can't understand how XOR works for 0b01101100 and 0b01100101. Why is it equal to 0b00001101 not to 0b00001001? Same question for every XOR.

Cool challenge, but a few notes:
 1) Although the input list mentions `C` as the 'global checksum', it wasn't entirely clear to me that the checksum needed to be applied to each set of characters.
 2) The stub generator has an issue, the `loop H read` should change to `loop N read`

Thank you a lot for pointing out that the Stub Generator was incorrect. I already fixed it.
About the first part, I think that it is clear enough (and you also have to think at least a little bit about the problem in a clash). But again, thank you very much for commenting.
You have this issue with 3rd digit from the end

I'm glad you like the idea. I know that the global checksum has no real use in this puzzle. You correctly observed that the puzzle is designed in such a way that "it cannot have 2 errors in the same set of 3 binary values" as it then would not be possible to solve without brute forcing. (at least that's what I think)
So you're going to check all languages?
Thank you very much for approving my contribution. I already removed the information from the hint and placed it outside of the hint section. I hope that I did what you meant.

I updated the description and hope that it is more clear now. And you definitely do not lack understanding in demodulation. You realized, that the value is unnecessary and that's great. I think that this is part of the challenge. Not only solving it, but also understanding that there are better, more efficient and clearer ways of using a checksum. There is only one reason to keep the global checksum: Making the people think about why I am using it and figuring out, that it is completely unnecessary. Everyone will see this flaw if they know about XORing.

That's the point. Of course there are puzzles that are much more complex, but those are usually placed in normal puzzles "easy", whereas this puzzle is a COC. Therefore I believe that a "unnecessary" value is indeed confusing, but part of the challenge. Of course I could've made it very easy, but then you won't have to think about it. (Now you have to at least think about the meaning of another value a little bit)
I totally agree on what you said. I also enjoy to figure things out, but you are right that the Fastest mode is the wrong category for thinking a lot. I updated the description.
Good choice, I think the puzzle is much clearer this way.

Perhaps I was a bit harsh with my previous comment (hope you didn't take it the wrong way) but now that you have edited the statement, the global checksum isn't as confusing and I'm okay with it.
I'm almost ready to approve the submission but I think you should remove the line "The global checksum is needed to recreate the values." as it is now clearly stated before.
Also why no shortest mode? I think it would be fun with this puzzle.

You're absolutely right, I already removed it but somehow messed up saving the description. Thank you for reminding me. I personally don't like shortest mode, but it would be a cool challenge too! (I added shortest mode too, even though I'm not a fan of it ;) )

Awesome, just validated your contribution.
Yeah I understand especially if you only know verbose languages like C or Java but at the same time it also offers a new perspective on the puzzle and forces you to think differently about the problem.

I think you didn't understand the meaning of the 3rd value and how it is generated. So, as described at the top, the 3rd value is generated by XORing three values. The first two values are the letters and the third value is the global checksum. All three values XORed will create the third value of each output (the checksum for each transmission)
